name: End
_source: speak;Fintan;Army of Crucible.{w}{clear}On behalf of the Duke of Setanta,{w} I wish to negotiate with the prince Marcel Milieu.
# yea these checks do nothing btw
speak;Claude;Marcel, don't go.{w}{clear}Better to stand and fight than to willingly put your head in the noose.{w}{clear}Come on,{w} it's not over yet,{w} we can still -
speak;Claudia;Hasn't it occurred to you that we all feel the exact same way?
speak;Claude;Then why aren't you saying anything?{w}{clear}Why are you letting him go?
speak;Marcel;Because nothing's set in stone, Claude.{w}{clear}We could work out a deal of some sort.{w}{clear}You don't know what happens until it happens.
speak;Marcel;We don't know until we know.
speak;Claude;If that's how it is,{w} then go.
speak;Madeline;I'll be able to live without you,{w} so long as you live.{w}{clear}If he tells you to leave me,{w} leave me.
speak;Marcel;I won't give up so easily.
# marcel's portrait appears. he looks back. Each of the crucibellian's portrait floats into position
# Marcel walks into the lion's den
speak;Fintan;Release the Duke's daughter and we'll let you live.
speak;Fintan;You're young.{w}{clear}You'll grow sick of her soon.
speak;Fintan;You're not leaving me a choice.
speak;Marcel;What do you know of choice?{w}{clear}You stand before me,{w} likely having never made a significant decision in your entire life.

speak;Marcel;Enough to be certain,{w} that to live a life like yours -{w}{clear}A sad, small, insignificant life where you follow the orders of a man above you -{w} can hardly be called a life at all.
speak;Fintan;Marcel, we're all born with great dreams inside us.{w}{clear}You haven't lived to see yours fade.
speak;Marcel;An excuse that doesn't excuse a thing.
speak;Fintan;I'm here because I had no choice.

speak;Marcel;You think so because you stand in the present,{w} see decisions made in the past that are now unalterable,{w} and so therefore conclude your choices made then,{w} in the prior present,{w} were beyond natural control.{w}{clear}Yet you stand in the present now,{w} the same present I inhabit,{w} and believe that I have a choice to make,{w} despite leaving me with no choices to pursue.{w}{clear}What kind of hypocrite are you?

speak;Fintan;Marcel.{w}{clear}We are enemies by circumstance.{w}{clear}I do not dislike you.{w}{clear}You have done well to get here.{w}{clear}I commend you.{w}{clear}But you cannot pretend you're a child.{w}{clear}You are accountable for your actions.{w}{clear}You cannot run off with a girl you happen to like,{w} without considering in life her position and yours.
speak;Marcel;I don't understand what you're trying to say and I doubt you do either.

speak;Fintan;Pretending again,{w} to not know the answer,{w} to answer like a child.{w}{clear}You know it's not proper.{w}{clear}You cannot go against the wishes of others,{w} and expect to be lauded for the effort.{w}{clear}It is natural that we seek to punish you.{w}{clear}If we allowed you,{w} we would allow everyone.{w}{clear}The very basis of society is to respect the wishes of others,{w} for the good of the whole population.{w}{clear}We can't have people like you in our midst:{w} Crucibellians,{w} doing as they please,{w} starting unprovoked wars,{w} stealing daughters from heads of state.{w}{clear}Our system would collapse otherwise.{w}{clear}You must understand this, Marcel,{w} if you are to live.{w}{clear}You cannot throw a tantrum to get what you want.{w}{clear}You must be polite.{w}{clear}Be kind to others.{w}{clear}Respect their desires.{w}{clear}That is what it means to live in a civilised society.

speak;Marcel;I'd sooner die than live in your so-called civilised society.{w}{clear}A society that drives people to isolation,{w} then has the audacity to turn around,{w} and lecture them on the habits of polite living.{w}{clear}A knife to my throat would be a favour.{w}{clear}You say it's my fault for the circumstances I find myself in -{w} but if people like you had the courage to live freely,{w} there wouldn't be soldiers for war.
speak;Fintan;Bitter words of a sore loser.

speak;Fintan;Any truth of yours is meaningless,{w} for you are alone,{w} and your actions and your attitudes will always ensure your loneliness,{w} and so will always ensure your powerlessness,{w} and so,{w} regardless of whatever personal revelations,{w} you will remain useless,{w} incapable of bringing any value to society as a whole,{w} owing to your childish refusal to play along with the wishes of other people.{w}{clear}Merely a case of natural selection,{w} that has left you alone,{w} and left me with control of an army.

speak;Marcel;Temporary, situational control granted due to sheer luck,{w} that you abuse,{w} call your God-given right,{w} just to kick me down on the ground.{w}{clear}A time will come when people like you:{w}{clear}Cowards who take up the business of murder to give up their right to be free,{w} to kill others who wish to live freely,{w} to kill those who point out their hypocrisy -{w}{clear}Nasty people like you with no regard for the lives of others -{w} people like you -
# to ensure the noise is not drowned out

speak;;The long grey sky calls down snow to a ground muddied by the steps of others. No shelter, together they huddle for warmth. You turn to the distance: a man's red hand stabs the ground with a boot at his feet. Face bitten with frost, he digs at the ice with the end of the steel-capped tip. Who know and do not know him don't try to speak, they see in his eyes he will die soon. You look at the ice, reflecting the sky, to see what it is that he breaks for. A shimmering flicker of glimmering light. A fire. Below. You break for it.;top_left;;clear;5;white;text;;8;;no_sound;no_block;hold

speak;;With fingernails you scrape the ice, hit with fists, stamp with boots. Blood from your knuckles dye in the snow red. Thousands of snowflakes whirl round your head, a thousand a second in front of your eyes, dancing around you, coming together, falling around you, breaking apart. In their delicately effervescent floating milieu, you can't feel your face, can't breathe without wincing, your eyes, half-blind, can't blink without tears. Your heart filled in strain clocking blows at the chest: the most painful reminder of effort in years. Eyes peer round at your face frost-bitten, to see in your eyes how to die soon.;top_left;;clear;5;white;text;;8;;no_sound;no_block;hold

speak;;They could hit the surface, to stamp the ground dead, but they are the product of passive acceptance. Blood in white snow still dyes red. The snow still falls around you. Through ice, you still see the fire below. Red like your hands, like the ground stained red by the hands stained red by the ground around you. You stand red-faced with the great weight of pressure. Your heart is tired, and body, cold. You try to break free, of the vice that surrounds you, but the arms won't move. The legs stand still. The eyes can't see the knees give way. The body falls, and falls, and falls. And the snow falls down around you.;top_left;;clear;5;white;text;;8;;no_sound;no_block;hold

speak;;Spinning around between life and death. The others left over will laugh at your efforts. And they will break, and the others left over will laugh at their efforts. And they will break, the others will break, the light in the sky at dawn will break and break the ice clean through but you'll be dead by then, and you'll die soon, so you better do something right quick because you won't be able to join in laughing at your own efforts at your own funeral. In front of your eyes is the fire below. It is up to you to break through.;top_left;;clear;5;white;text;;8;;no_sound

speak;;The reflection shatters, the ice breaks down, and you fall through, and fall and tumble and bleed and crash and bleed and fall still. By the heart's side in the hearth's wide fire, heart-wide fire eyes fire eyes wide to an eyes-wide fire, firing fire, small where the hearth sits small where the heart lies wide where the heart's wide fireside full of the words of your mother come through to you.;top_left;;clear;4.5;white;text;hold;9;no_sound;no_block;no_warn;hold
speak;;Even if the world stands against you.;center;;clear;1;yellow;text;hold;;no_sound;no_block;no_warn

speak;Madeline;Marcel!{w} Marcel!{w} Speak to me!{w} Marcel!;;90;;;;;;1
speak;;What do you expect me to do?;top_right;120;thought_bubble;no_block;hold
speak;Marcel;What's the matter, Madeline?{w}{clear}What's going on?
speak;Marcel;Come on, Madeline,{w} stop,{w} stop crying.

speak;Marcel;Cheer up, Madeline,{w} walk with me, Madeline,{w} Madeline,{w} Madeline,{w} Madeline,{w} walk with me.{w}{clear}Back where we used to sit,{w} back where we used to be.{w}{clear}Back where we used to sit back at the house.{w}{clear}We can relax.{w}{clear}Speak like we used to.{w}{clear}Watch the sun set with me.{w}{clear}Watch it now, actually.{w}{clear}Hey,{w} Madeline.{w}{clear}Where are you going?
speak;Madeline;I'm here! I'm right here! I'm right here I'm right here I'm right -;hold;no_block
speak;Marcel;Don't follow Madeline,{w} what's there to say?{w}{clear}The day still ends at the end of the day.{w}{clear}Cheer up, Madeline,{w} as long as it shines,;;;;3
speak;Marcel;As long as the sun's still up,;;;;4
